column1: Factor VII (seven) deficiency is a disorder caused by a lack of a protein called factor VII in the blood.
Factor VII deficiency runs in families (inherited) and is very rare.
It can be caused by: - Low vitamin K (some babies are born with vitamin K deficiency) - Severe liver disease - Use of medicines that prevent clotting (anticoagulants such as warfarin)
Bleeding can be controlled by getting intravenous (IV) infusions of normal plasma, concentrates of factor VII, or genetically produced (recombinant) factor VII.
- Tell your family members because they may have the same disorder but do not know it yet.
